conclusion: Consider Faraday's Law of Induction to find the maximum induced EMF.
For a uniform magnetic field, magnetic flux Φ = BA, where A is the area inside the field.
EMF can be expressed as B(dA/dt) due to constant velocity v.
Rate of change of area is B(l × v), where l is the length of the conductor moving perpendicularly.
The loop is an equilateral triangle with side length a.
The x-axis is horizontal, pointing to the right (direction of velocity v).
The y-axis is vertical.
Line MN is at x=0.
Point D starts entering the magnetic field at t=0.
Side CD is always perpendicular to MN, meaning CD is horizontal in the diagram.
The angle of an equilateral triangle is 60°.
The loop enters the magnetic field from t=0 until point C enters the field.
The part of the conductor cutting the magnetic field lines is the part inside the field and perpendicular to the direction of motion.
The induced EMF is given by EMF = BLv, where L is the length of the segment within the field perpendicular to v.
Let x be the distance point D has moved into the magnetic field.
The height of an equilateral triangle is h = a sin(60°) = a√3/2.
Points D and C are on a horizontal line, point E is below this line.
Side CD has length a.
Vertex E is at a horizontal distance of a/2 from the line through D and C.
Vertical height from CD to E is a√3/2.
Side CD is horizontal, and the triangle moves to the right with velocity v.
The magnetic field starts at the vertical line MN.
Point D is the first point of the triangle to enter the magnetic field.
